user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of parse_bauth_params:
```c
static bool
parse_bauth_params (const char *str,
                    size_t str_len,
                    struct MHD_RqBAuth *pbauth)
{
  size_t i;

  i = 0;

  /* Skip all whitespaces at start */
  while (i < str_len && (' ' == str[i] || '\t' == str[i]))
    i++;

  if (str_len > i)
  {
    size_t token68_start;
    size_t token68_len;

    /* 'i' points to the first non-whitespace char after scheme token */
    token68_start = i;
    /* Find end of the token. Token cannot contain whitespace. */
    while (i < str_len && ' ' != str[i] && '\t' != str[i])
    {
      if (0 == str[i])
        return false;  /* Binary zero is not allowed */
      if ((',' == str[i]) || (';' == str[i]))
        return false;  /* Only single token68 is allowed */
      i++;
    }
    token68_len = i - token68_start;
    mhd_assert (0 != token68_len);

    /* Skip all whitespaces */
    while (i < str_len && (' ' == str[i] || '\t' == str[i]))
      i++;
    /* Check whether any garbage is present at the end of the string */
    if (str_len != i)
      return false;
    else
    {
      /* No more data in the string, only single token68. */
      pbauth->token68.str = str + token68_start;
      pbauth->token68.len = token68_len;
    }
  }
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function parse_bauth_params:
const struct MHD_RqBAuth *
MHD_get_rq_bauth_params_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct _MHD_str_w_len h_auth_value;
  struct MHD_RqBAuth *bauth;

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED <= connection->state);

  if (connection->rq.bauth_tried)
    return connection->rq.bauth;

  if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > connection->state)
    return NULL;

  if (! find_auth_rq_header_ (connection, MHD_AUTHTYPE_BASIC, &h_auth_value))
  {
    connection->rq.bauth_tried = true;
    connection->rq.bauth = NULL;
    return NULL;
  }

  bauth =
    (struct MHD_RqBAuth *)
    MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (connection, sizeof (struct MHD_RqBAuth));

  if (NULL == bauth)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Not enough memory in the connection's pool to allocate " \
                 "for Basic Authorization header parsing.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    return NULL;
  }

  memset (bauth, 0, sizeof(struct MHD_RqBAuth));
  if (parse_bauth_params (h_auth_value.str, h_auth_value.len, bauth))
    connection->rq.bauth = bauth;
  else
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("The Basic Authorization client's header has "
                 "incorrect format.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    connection->rq.bauth = NULL;
    /* Memory in the pool remains allocated until next request */
  }
  connection->rq.bauth_tried = true;
  return connection->rq.bauth;
}
...
struct MHD_RqBAuth
{
  struct _MHD_str_w_len token68;
}
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are compile-time invariant (constant) in the provided code that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. All control expressions depend on runtime values or memory contents and therefore are not invariant: 

- while (i < str_len && (' ' == str[i] || '\t' == str[i])) depends on i, str_len and str[i].
- while (i < str_len && ' ' != str[i] && '\t' != str[i]) depends on i, str_len and str[i].
- if (0 == str[i]) and if ((',' == str[i]) || (';' == str[i])) depend on str[i].
- if (str_len > i), if (str_len != i) depend on runtime values of str_len and i.
- In the additional code, checks such as if (connection->rq.bauth_tried), if (MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_PROCESSED > connection->state), and if (NULL == bauth) similarly depend on runtime state.

Note on mhd_assert: the macro is defined as ((void)0) so the mhd_assert (0 != token68_len); statement is removed at compile time; this is not a controlling expression and does not introduce an invariant loop or condition. If the intent was to enforce a runtime check, the empty macro might hide that, but this is not a Rule 14.3 invariant-expression issue.

Given the above, there are no code fragments that appear to violate Rule 14.3 (controlling expressions that are compile-time invariant). If you want, I can flag places where runtime bounds/validations could be strengthened (e.g., explicit check for zero-length token before using token pointers) but that would be a different MISRA rule scope.
